data.title: Cache npm cache in CI
data.body:
This should improve CI build time as a big time is spent on installing dependencies :)

Note that this caches the npm cache folder, which is safe as opposed to caching node_modules directly.

data.body:
Can someone help me with this issue?

I have an issue about the local branch. I have using VS Code for months. In this few month I have open a few branch on my local and I have push the commit to my server. But I have found out that the list havent been updated. But my branch had been delete on my server. So does anyone know how to refresh the list so that my VS Code branch list are same with my remote branch list.

data.title: Have Cmd+R(Mac) and Ctrl+R(Win) reload window by default
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write code that depends on typings or a module that isn't installed yet or isn't yet correct.
2. Install the correct typings or module, and then find yourself struggling to get the Problems panes to update for all the open files (eventually finding multi-step solutions).

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

I originally asked for help with this on SO: [Refreshing errors in VSC after installing typings](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46461014/refreshing-errors-in-vsc-after-installing-typings)

I eventually found a solution: Map Command+R (on a Mac) or Control+R (on Windows) to `workbench.action.reloadWindow`. Now all I have to do to refresh the errors is to hit the same key combo I would in any browser to refresh the page.

Amazingly, it seems that Command+R and Control+R are not already mapped on Mac and Windows.

SUGGESTION: Add this to the default mappings, in order to make users' lives easier. It'll at least make my life easier by keeping VSC from later mapping this to something else I might also need.

Of course, it's also possible that I went on a wild goose chase and there is another, better way to make life easier. If so, please advise me. Thanks!

data.title: Can we have a better mouse to caret positioning?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

I know this convention is half one way, half the other...

For as long as text editors have existed there has been 2 conventions on mouse to caret positioning

One, which is what Code used now, is the annoying clicking anyway on a character places the caret in front of the character (Notepad)

The other, better imho, is if you click on a character, which ever side of the character, the left or the right, the mouse is, that is where the caret will be placed. (Notepad ++, this one seem to place the caret to the front clicking on the left 2/3rd of the character and to the back clicking the right 1/3rd). Which reduces the selection error quite drastically. 

Is there a way to set that up in the settings?


Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-autohotkey|sle|0.2.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.
2.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Can we choose another method for barce matching?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Brace matching is great but my problem is the way the brace are highlighted with the 2 squares that almost touch when the 2 braces are next to each other, giving me this faux caret illusion....

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6321426/31059908-1a6217d2-a6d7-11e7-8eb0-d82bcd01e510.png)

If I take a quick look at the screen while the caret has blinked off, my mind assume this area between the 2 squares is my carret. And that makes for quite a few issues, especially combined with the mouse clicking to place the caret... which places the caret in front of the clicked character instead of whatever side of the character is closes to the mouse. I will report on that separate issue


Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-autohotkey|sle|0.2.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.
2.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: add ignoreCurrentOpen user settings to address #6923

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Added the boolean "ignoreCurrentOpen" in the workbench.quickOpen user settings which controls whether the current open file should be focused under the Quick Open action.
Addresses #6923 
true does not focus the current open file.
false focuses the current open file (default and the current behaviour).

data.title: Use block comment for every line if line comments are not supported by language
data.body:
There are some languages which don't support line comments: xml, html, ml, maybe more. In case of such languages VSCode uses block comments, when user invokes **editor.action.addCommentLine** or **editor.action.commentLine**.

When I select some code and toggle line comment, I expect this:

![linecomment](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2060295/31059140-2bc69cec-a708-11e7-8c96-cb3e738474ec.png)

But, in fact, I got this:

![blockcomment](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2060295/31059139-2a863338-a708-11e7-8f99-bc9215678c59.png)

I think it would be better to implement following behaviour: _if line comment is not specified by extension and user invokes line comment command - use block comment for every line_

data.title: Fix for #32342
data.body: When expanding abbreviations, do so from bottom to top.  This way a change higher up will not interfere with text below.

data.title: No global setting to hide unwanted sidebar panels installed by extensions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.16.1 - OS Version: macOS 10.13 Here's what I get if I create a new window: Those things screaming at me in all-caps at the bottom ("XML DOCUMENT", "PROJECTS", "COMPARE COMMITS", etc.) have no relevance to me and their functionality is unwanted. I want the functionality that the extensions provide, but not the panels. For example, I use the Project Manager extension to switch between projects, but its sidebar panel is completely pointless. (As an aside, I don't know why they're not context-aware. Why is "XML DOCUMENT", which is a panel that shows an XML document's structure, visible when I don't have an XML document open? Why doesn't it automatically open when I view an XML document? Why isn't there a command palette command to show/hide it? Why is there a panel dedicated to XML instead of a generic "editor structure" panel, anyway? I have many questions.) I can right-click and select "Remove from Sidebar", and they go away, until I open another window. I have to repeat this process for every new window I open. These annoying things should, at best, be opt-in, not opt-out. The only extension which is sensible enough to have a global setting is the official Docker extension, which has `docker.showExplorer`.

data.title: [question] how to develop vscode extensions locally with inter dependencies
data.body:
I'm attempting to develop extensions which have a common dependency.
I use `npm link` to satisfy the dependency locally.

The problem is that I can't package the extension because `vsce` will fail due to `npm` saying there are extraneous modules.  This is due to both modules requiring `vscode`.

The annoying work around is to uninstall the `vscode` from the common module before I package/publish.  But this is an annoying workflow.

Is there a way to make this work properly?

data.title: Can't reset font size after zooming with mouse wheel

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.2
block-travel|sas|0.0.2
selectline-statusbar|tom|0.0.2


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

---

Currently there are two ways to change font size: by zooming the UI with keyboard shortcuts or menu options and by ctrl+scrolling with `"editor.mouseWheelZoom": true` . But it is impossible to reset the zoom level after zooming with mouse wheel except by restarting the editor. 

The issue stems from this: ctrl+scrolling changes the font size independent from the UI zoom level, and "Zoom In/Zoom Out/Reset Zoom" actions change the UI zoom level (which affects visible font size) but not the font size set by the former.

Here's a recording of me (using a fresh VS Code Insiders 1.17.0 build) ctrl+scrolling (zooming out) then changing the UI zoom level then ctrl+scrolling again (zooming in). You can see that the changes to font size are impossible to reset, they don't even register in the settings file.

![2017-09-28_15-33-29](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7759622/30966831-f10a2a8a-a462-11e7-8328-797380aca23b.gif)

data.title: Disable fading scrollbars

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: There should be a way to disable fading scrollbars.  I like the scrollbars to always appear so I can always see at-a-glance where I am in the document.

data.title: Drag and Drop text copies it instead of moving
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Win10x64

Sometime Drag and Drop'ing text copies it instead of moving (without holding ctrl). It's extremely annoying since it doesn't change the cursor and a copy of a viable chunk of code wouldn't normally trigger linter to complain or even produce a runtime error, but it surely would mess with the output. I only notice it when reviewing my changes in GIT or when this happens after dragging text very short distances, like into the next/prev line. But 3+ lines away it is already easy to miss. 

I don't know how to repro it - happens to me maybe once-twice per work session. I've only noticed that when I do notice this behavior, as long as I don't "disturb" it - it keeps on going, i.e. if I just copied a piece of text this way, if I don't select another chunk or press ctrl or change the tab - every subsequent drag-moving of this still selected piece of text would create a new copy. My first reaction to this is "oh, my ctrl key probably stuck" so I press it a couple of times and it "helps" but as I said, the cursor doesn't even change and there would be a multitude of other things happening if it ware a stuck key, since typing would turn into hotkeying.

Thank you.

data.title: WorkspaceConfiguration.get doesn't respect defaultValue parameter
Workspace-level key bindings?
data.body: I think support should be introduced for a keybindings.json in the project's `.vscode` folder which would override globally-defined key bindings.  This would allow me to remap certain key bindings for a given project and make sure I don't lose them by checking them into source control.

data.title: FileSystemProvide API should declare enums starting with 1
data.body:
The type in question is:

```ts
	export enum FileType {
		File = 0,
		Dir = 1,
		Symlink = 2
	}
```

Having 0 as a value only causes problems with default interpretation and the absence of properties. I only use 0 if this is equal to the property no being there.

data.title: Issue debugging a .NET core application
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.17
- OS Version: Fedora 26

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set up dotnet and the C# plugin from [OnmiSharp](https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/)
2. Set up a debugging session

I then get this error, which is annoying because I downloaded the plugin directly from OmniSharp, which it looks like the extension tab then replaces it with Microsofts proprietary version of it, which is pretty shady...

```
-------------------------------------------------------------------
You may only use the Microsoft .NET Core Debugger (vsdbg) with
Visual Studio Code, Visual Studio or Visual Studio for Mac software
to help you develop and test your applications.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
```
